instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3536: What is 820-3536? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with a half-shorted <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi,
I've got this board and it's giving me trouble.
It will not start because <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> only has 1.8V
When I measure resistance to ground, I get about 130 Ohms, while a good board has approx 1KOhm
Thing is 130 Ohms is too much to be able to get the bad guy to get hot enough to find it.

I've tried to inject 3.3V anyway, and didn't indeed find anything especially hot.
But after I did that and let the voltage run for a few minutes, I was able to see the board was sometimes booting and sometimes not. I connected a speaker to be certain and I did hear a chime.
Now, the next day, the board doesn't boot anymore.

I'm not quite sure what to do from here. I can't really consider removing all the stuff on the <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL> rail until the 130Ohms to ground goes away, there's just too much stuff.
So any suggestion would be more than welcome :)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with a half-shorted <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Any history available, liquid signs?
Can be a low value caused by accumulated crap under some BGA chip.
Also inspect all big ceramic caps on that line; remove the ones which look ugly/strange.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with a half-shorted <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I don't really know the history. I got this board from a joblot off ebay. At first it was totally missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>, with a dead short to ground. There was clear signs of liquid spill in the corner near the headphones jack, and especially, the microphone ribbon cable connector looked really nasty.
So I removed that connector and cleaned the pads. Then I got what I described above, which is no longer a dead short but still not quite a normal resistance for that rail.

I've already looked at all the caps on that rail, and none of them really look bad, unfortunately.

If there's crap under a BGA chip, I guess it could be the audio codec, since it's pretty close to the area where the dead short was.

But I noticed one thing, though. <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> is created from <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> through a mosfet switch. I do see 1.8V on the S0 rail, but the S5 rail has a clean 3.3V.
Shouldn't the short also drive the S5 rail down to 1.8V ? This makes me think I should maybe replace the mosfet for the S0 rail. Would you agree ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with a half-shorted <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Yes, is a good start.

BTW, do not quote an entire post visible few centimeters above.
I don't see any real reason...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with a half-shorted <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Yeah sorry about the quote, I don't usually do that. Not sure why I did it here, my mistake.
So, I have removed the mosfet, and I now see about 1kohm to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>, which looks much better.
I don't have a replacement mosfet at hand, so I'll have to get some from aliexpress and it will take a while, but it really looks like the problem did come from there.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with a half-shorted <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
If you deal with Apple stuff, buy scrap boards from Aliexpress.
You can get good price, if buy bulk and directly from the seller.
Then you get SMCs and lot of rare components...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with a half-shorted <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Yeah, I do have a few scrap boards, but that mosfet is a raw die BGA. I haven't had much success trying to reball those in the past, unlike regular BGA packages. Not quite sure why.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with a half-shorted <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message: You don't need to reball such a small chip; solder it directly...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with a half-shorted <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Yeah, I tried what you said, and I was indeed able to solder it directly.
And replacing that mosfet fixed the board. <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> now runs at 3.3V and the board gives me a fanspin and a chime.
Thanks !
